Staff Accused of Domestic Abuse or Stalking - Guidance for Managers .................... 19
Introduction
This policy sets out the Mid & South Essex University Hospitals Trust (MSE) policy on supporting staff experiencing domestic abuse and stalking.

Domestic abuse is a complex issue that needs sensitive handling by a range of health and social care professionals. Individuals experiencing domestic abuse, whether the abused, the abuser or those witnessing abuse within the home environment, should have access to the support they need when they need it, to be safe, or address behaviour.

For the year ending March 2019, the Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) showed that an estimated  million adults aged  to  years experienced domestic abuse in the last year. This equates to a prevalence rate of approximately 6 in 100 adults. The abuse can encompass, but is not limited to psychological, physical, sexual, financial, emotional, controlling behaviour or forced marriage. In terms of the types of abuse experienced in the last year, non-sexual domestic abuse (which comprises physical force, emotional abuse, financial abuse, threats and force) was the most common type of domestic abuse experienced by adults (5.2%), domestic stalking was experienced by 1.1% of adults, domestic sexual assault was experienced by 0.4% of adults.
MSE recognises that some of its staff will be among those affected by domestic abuse and/or stalking or harassment.

Individuals have a right to live safely as enshrined by Articles 2, 3, 8 and 12 in the Human Rights Act. In accordance with the NHS constitution, the NHS ‘has a duty to each and every individual that it serves and it must protect their Human Rights'.

Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) believes that everyone has the right to live free from fear and abuse and is therefore committed to developing a workplace culture in which there is zero tolerance of violence and other forms of abuse.

People may be affected by domestic abuse in a number of ways, for example being a survivor of domestic violence, currently living with an abusive partner or family member or themselves being a perpetrator of domestic abuse. MSE is committed to creating a workplace where employees feel comfortable discussing domestic abuse, stalking and harassment and feel able to seek help with any concerns.
This policy is based on the following principles:

Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) is committed to providing practical and emotional support for any of its staff members who suffer domestic abuse, stalking or any other form of threat, violence or harassment.

All disclosures of domestic abuse, stalking or harassment will be responded to sensitively and the organisation will seek to support staff who have experienced or are experiencing domestic abuse in any of its forms.
Violence is never an acceptable method of solving conflict in relationships. Responsibility for violence rests entirely with the perpetrator.

All victims of domestic abuse are entitled to being supported in the spirit of this policy in line with the Trust commitment to equality, diversity and free from discrimination that may be related to:
Age
Disability
Gender reassignment
Marriage and civil partnership
Pregnancy and maternity
Race
Religion and belief
Sex
Sexual Orientation

Domestic abuse, stalking and harassment may not only be criminal offences but are also serious disciplinary offences which may impact on a perpetrators employment with the Trust. Issues will be dealt with under the Trust's disciplinary procedures where evidence comes to light. This is because it would not be appropriate for the Trust to employ staff who could pose a risk to vulnerable patients or bring the organisation into disrepute. Such incidents will often be treated as gross misconduct which can lead to dismissal without notice. Staff should be aware that while the ‘burden of proof' in criminal cases is “beyond reasonable doubt”; the Trust will make its decision ‘on the balance of probability' and does not need the same level of evidence as in a criminal trial to take action.

The Trust respects employees' right to privacy. Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) strongly encourages victims of domestic abuse and/or stalking to disclose information for the safety of themselves and their colleagues, who may also be at risk if the perpetrator comes into the workplace. However, the organisation does not force staff to disclose this information if they do not wish to.
MSE requires perpetrators of domestic violence to declare any related prosecutions. Failure to declare a charge, caution or conviction in a timely way may result in disciplinary action being taken.

If the Trust has grounds to believe that a member of staff may have been engaging in domestic abuse and/or stalking behaviour, whether or not there has been a formal complaint, the Trust will instigate an appropriate investigation into any alleged misconduct and may take disciplinary action as a result.
The Trust will cooperate with other agencies in relation to preventing and responding to domestic violence and stalking.

Any malicious complaints may result in the Disciplinary Policy and Procedure being invoked. An example of this would be if one member of staff makes an untrue allegation against another member of staff as a result of a personal dispute with the aim of getting them into trouble.
This policy is written in line with and promotes the Trust's values of care with compassion, working together and being professional and accountable.
Scope

This Policy applies to all employees of the Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) and others including patients, visitors, partnership and agency staff, contractors, volunteers,  students  and  those  on  work  experience  who  may  be  affected  by  the organisation's work activities.
The purpose of this policy is to:

Ensure that all employees know that help is available if domestic violence in any of its forms is an issue for them and to provide sources of information and support to staff who are victims of domestic abuse and/or stalking.
Provide practical advice to managers on how to deal with situations where domestic abuse is disclosed or there is evidence which leads to domestic abuse being suspected.
To provide details of support agencies for staff members who are faced with issues resulting from domestic violence or stalking
Set out the Trust's expectations of staff and to send out a clear message that domestic abuse is unacceptable and disciplinary action against perpetrators of domestic Violence may be considered.

Provide clear direction for service provision following national guidance based on key legislation including Serious Crime Act 2015 (section 76), Preventing and Combating Violence against Woman and Domestic Violence Act 2017, Domestic Violence, Crime and Victims Act 2004 (amended 2012).
Set out examples of the different forms of domestic abuse and stalking
Set out the actions that will be taken in responding to employees who are experiencing domestic abuse and where there are concerns that an employee may be the perpetrator of domestic abuse.
Mitigate the risks associated with domestic abuse
This policy will enable the organisation to:
Improve safety and health by recognising that domestic abuse is a serious crime which may have an adverse impact on individuals, families and communities.
Increase knowledge and understanding about the nature of domestic abuse and its impact on those who experience domestic abuse and their dependents.
Comply with the legal framework and current national guidance.
Support effective inter-agency communication.
Provide guidance and support to all staff.
Raise awareness on the incidence of domestic abuse.
Definitions

table_items.text: Any incident of threatening behaviour, violence or abuse (psychological, physical, sexual, financial or emotional) between adults who are or have been intimate partners or family members, regardless of gender or sexuality. “Any incident or pattern of incidents of controlling, coercive or threatening behaviour, violence or abuse between those aged 16 or over who are or have been intimate partners or family members regardless of gender or

sexuality. This can encompass, but is not limited to, the following types of abuse: psychological physical sexual financial emotional” Home Office November 2013 Domestic abuse also covers issues such as forced marriage, female genital mutilation and abuse and violence in the name of honour (also called ‘honour'-based violence). 90% of domestic abuse cases are committed by men against women, but it is important to recognise that women also commit domestic abuse and Lesbian Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) relationships are also affected by domestic abuse

Someone's behaviour is coercive when they force, pressurise, bully or intimidate someone, usually to make them do something they do not wish to do or to stop them doing something they want to do. “Coercive behaviour is: an act or a pattern of acts of assault, threats, humiliation and intimidation or other abuse that is used to harm, punish, or frighten their victim.” Home Office November 2013 On the 29th December 2015 controlling or coercive became a criminal offence under the Serious Crime Act 2015 and carries a maximum sentence of 5 years imprisonment, a fine or both

Controlling behaviour is behaviour which is jealous, domineering, selfish and/or overprotective where someone tries to dominate another person. “Controlling behaviour is: a range of acts designed to make a person subordinate and/or dependent by isolating them from sources of support, exploiting their resources and capacities for personal gain, depriving them of the means needed for independence, resistance and escape and regulating their everyday behaviour.” (Home Office November 2013)

Child protection is “activity to protect specific children who are suffering or likely to suffer significant harm” (Department for Education 2018). Violence and other abuse will often be witnessed by children and there is an overlap between the abuse of women and abuse of children. The wide adverse effects of living with domestic abuse for children must be recognized as a child protection issue. It is linked to children experiencing poor educational achievement, social exclusion and to juvenile crime, substance misuse, mental health problems and homelessness from running away. Research has also shown that where domestic abuse is present within a family setting, the child may experience emotional abuse themselves and/or possibly "pattern" the abusive behaviour.

There is sometimes confusion between forced and arranged marriages. However, the distinction is clear; an arranged marriage involves the full consent from both persons involved, whilst forced marriage is a marriage conducted without valid consent of one or both parties where duress is a factor. Forced marriage can involve coercion, manipulation, pressure or threat for the person/s to fulfil the vows of marriage. Forced marriage is not a religious or cultural issue - it is a human rights

An 'honour' based crime covers a range of violent and abusive acts committed in the name of honour, including all forms of domestic violence from harassment to homicide. An 'honour' code is a set of 'moral' rules for family or community members, established at the discretion of (usually male) relatives and interpreted accordingly. Violence and abuse can occur when perpetrators perceive that a relative has shamed the family and / or community by breaking their honour code. Most honour based violence is perpetrated by husbands against wives, and fathers against daughters, but males can also be victimised, for example if they are gay or are believed to be supporting the victim. The following incidents can be triggers for abuse and violence in the name of honour: Having a boyfriend Rejecting a forced marriage Being lesbian or gay Becoming pregnant outside of marriage Having an interfaith relationship or a relationship with someone from a different social or cultural group Leaving a marriage or seeking divorce Not conforming to a dress code Victims are sometimes pressurised or tricked into going abroad where they are then killed. Honour Based Violence can be distinguished from other forms of violence, as it is often committed with some degree of approval and/or collusion from family and/or community members. Such crimes cut across all cultures, nationalities, faith groups and communities. They transcend national and international boundaries.

Includes slapping, pushing, kicking, scalding, inflicting burns, stabbing, and damage to property or items of sentimental value, choking, biting, poisoning, attempted murder and murder. This can be against the victim or against children, family members or pets in order to intimidate the victim.
Includes controlling who the victim sees or where they go, what they wear or do, stalking, imprisonment and forced marriage.
This is the common term used when a victim of domestic abuse tells someone about what is happening to them.
Includes stealing, depriving or taking control of money, running up debts, withholding benefit books or bank cards

Includes intimidation and threats, social isolation, verbal abuse, humiliation, constant criticism and enforced trivial routines. Being stopped from seeing friends or relatives Constantly being insulted or belittled, including in front of others. Being kept awake or prevented from sleeping. Excessive contact, for example stalking. Using social media sites to intimidate (such as Facebook and Twitter)
Includes any non-consensual sexual activity, rape, sexual assault, coercive sexual activity or refusing safer sex

A form of harassment which generally involves repeated, persistent following with no legitimate reason. Stalking may take place with the intention of harming the person being stalked or creating anxiety or fear of harm in the person being followed. Stalking may also take the form of harassing telephone calls, computer communications, letter-writing. On 25 November 2012, two specific criminal offences of 'stalking' and 'stalking involving fear of violence or alarm or distress' came into force in England and Wales, along with additional related police search powers. The provisions will provide extra protection for victims, highlight the serious impact stalking can have on their lives, and help bring more perpetrators to justice. Home Office 2012 ( A change to the Protection from Harassment Act 1997)

Some people prefer to use the word 'survivor' to describe people going through or moving on from experiencing domestic violence as this acknowledges the survival skills required to survive domestic violence. Others prefer the word 'victim' as this acknowledges that they are or have been victimised by a perpetrator. The word 'victim' also acknowledges that those experiencing domestic violence are (usually) victims of crime
Somebody who is responsible for committing an act of domestic abuse or stalking.
Young people subjected to domestic abuse

The changes to the definition of ‘domestic abuse' raise awareness that young people in the 16 to 17 age group can also be subjected to domestic abuse. By including this age group the government hopes to encourage young people to come forward and get the support they need, through a helpline or specialist service.

Is anyone who has not yet reached his/her 18th birthday (Children's Act 1989). Witnessing domestic abuse is distressing for a child and causes serious harm (SET 2018). Domestic Abuse involving young people under the age of 18 years, even though they may be parents, is classified as child abuse and should be dealt with under Safeguarding Local Child Protection Procedures. A parent is a person with parental responsibility.
Is defined as any person aged 18 and over.

Is an adult who is or may be in need of community care services by reason of mental or other disability, age or illness; and who is or may be unable to take care of him or herself, or unable to protect him or herself against significant harm or exploitation
Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE)

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Chief Nurse

The Chief Nurse, as Executive Lead for Safeguarding, is responsible for ensuring that the Trust Board / Executive is aware of, and discharges its statutory safeguarding duties in supporting staff members that disclose domestic abuse.
All Staff are required to promote the principles in this policy by:

Responding sensitively and appropriately if someone who is the subject of domestic abuse or stalking discloses this information. Staff should never advise the victim what to do but should encourage them to seek advice and support from an appropriate source e.g. a specialist organisation such as Compass, Changing Pathways, Refuge, Women's Aid, and Safer Places, internally via Human Resources or Occupational Health. (See Appendix 2 for contacts).

Being aware of how their own behaviour and comments may affect others and changing it, if necessary. You may not be aware that a colleague is suffering domestic abuse so be sensitive in what you say – even jokes can be hugely hurtful and damaging.
Taking a stand if they think inappropriate jokes or comments are being made. (For more information on this please see the Trust's Dignity and respect Policy).
Discreetly and confidentially reporting any concerns or incidents that they experience or witness to an appropriate senior manager or Human Resources and co-operating with Trust investigations.

Not prejudging or victimising someone who makes a complaint of domestic abuse or stalking or someone who is accused of abuse. Staff will not always have all of the facts and it is for the Trust to deal with any issues which may arise through the proper channels, which may include through the disciplinary process or reporting issues to
the police.
Service Leads are required to:
Ensure that there is a supportive working environment which is conducive to staff being able to disclose concerns regarding domestic abuse and stalking.
Familiarising themselves with the guidance available in the appendices to this policy and acting in accordance with them.
Intervening appropriately at an early stage where they have concerns about the welfare or behaviour of a member of staff, seeking advice from Human Resources.
Ensuring that any allegations against staff members of domestic abuse and/or stalking are referred correctly to safeguarding and resolved as quickly as possible.
Ensure a strict level of confidentiality is maintained at all times regarding Trust staff who disclose Domestic abuse.
Understanding the need to balance the personal needs of employees with the organisation's needs.

Undertake – Support risk assessments and safety planning, to ensure the safety of staff, with support and advice from Human Resources and the Adult Safeguarding Lead and specialist external organisations.

4.3.1  Managers are often best placed to be aware of issues in an employee's personal life. Putting in place support systems such as referral to Occupational Health may help the member of staff address the issues they are facing. However, managers are not expected to be experts on domestic abuse and should never offer advice or guidance to staff on how they should act but should give staff the information to enable them to contact specialist organisations who can provide expert advice and support.
Human Resources are responsible for:
Providing advice and support to managers to help them to respond appropriately to disclosures or suspicions of domestic abuse and/or stalking and to investigate incidents.
Acting as a source of confidential support for staff with concerns, providing information on professional organisations who can offer specialist support.
Maintaining appropriate data relating to reported cases of domestic abuse and
stalking.
Safeguarding Team is responsible for:
Referring any safeguarding concerns around domestic abuse to relevant local authority.
Referring any adults disclosing domestic abuse on to outside specialist organisations if individual agrees.
Considering requests from individuals and their line managers for additional support from security staff.
Acting as a source of confidential support for staff with concerns, providing information on professional organisations who can offer specialist support.
Supporting the implementation of staff safety planning where appropriate and agreeing time lined strategies with all parties involved.
Considering requests from individuals and their line managers for alternative car parking arrangements where appropriate.
Reviewing security measures in light of any concerns, risks or incidents relating to domestic abuse and/or stalking.
Liaising with the Police and outside agencies when appropriate.
Staffside Representatives are responsible for:

Providing informed advice and support to union members who approach them for help in relation to domestic abuse or stalking. However, staffside representatives are not expected to be experts on domestic abuse and should never offer advice or guidance to staff on how they should act but should give staff the information to enable them to contact specialist organisations who can provide expert advice and support.

Encouraging and supporting staff to work with the Trust and to seek the Trust's support to resolve concerns constructively and at the earliest possible stage to avoid them escalating into more serious issues.
Occupational Health is responsible for:

Providing managers with impartial and factual occupational health information in order to assist them to manage workplace issues effectively. This would be done in line with the Trust's usual approach to Occupational Health referrals with regard to staff consent.
Providing informed advice and support to staff who approach them for help in relation to any health problems experienced as a result of issues relating to domestic abuse or stalking.
Providing a confidential counselling service to staff.
Encouraging and supporting staff to resolve any issues through established mechanisms e.g. informally through their line management chain or through formal procedures.
Engaging with the HR department to highlight any intervention required, seeking the consent of their clients where appropriate.
Operational Adult and Child Safeguarding Committees oversee all Operational safeguarding children activity including training compliance and adherence to policies;

MSE Committee in Common oversees assurance to the Trust Board that policies, systems and procedures and in place, disseminated and adhered to, to safeguard children, young people and adults at risk. Provides assurance on the implementation, monitoring and updating of policies, systems and procedures within
the Trust for safeguarding children, young people and adults at risk. Responding to changes in local and national guidance, legislation and best practice.
Main procedure for supporting staff experiencing domestic
violence

The policy provides a framework for staff and managers to deal with situations relating to domestic abuse in all its forms. However, each individual is different and therefore will require different support from the organisation. Individuals may choose to disclose issues of domestic abuse and/ or stalking through a variety of different routes. Victims may choose not to disclose any information to the Trust but may prefer to access this policy for information on sources of support available to them outside the Trust.
The policy is split into three sections to cover domestic abuse, stalking and those staff who are accused of domestic abuse or stalking.
Why would an employer get involved in domestic abuse and stalking?

As well as trying to do the right thing for staff, there is a business case for supporting staff that are experiencing domestic abuse and stalking. There is a cost to the organisation in terms of staff morale, wellbeing, productivity, absenteeism and the reputation of the organisation in the community.

Line managers, are well placed to notice any issues with members of staff that may be indicators of domestic violence, such as lateness, increased sickness absence, a drop in performance and changes in behaviour and mood. There are a number of indicators of domestic abuse, of which managers should be aware. These include:
Physical
Stress-related ailments – headaches, irritable bowel syndrome;
Bruises on the body, particularly on the breasts and abdomen;
Injuries to face, head or neck;
Multiple injuries in different stages of healing;
Burns – cigarette burns, rope burns;
Hair loss – consistent with hair pulling;
Unexplained injuries or those inconsistent with explanations;
Behavioural
Frequent A & E visits;
Appears fearful, evasive, ashamed, embarrassed;
Use of alcohol and drugs (e.g. use of tranquillisers);
Eating disorders;
Frequent use of pain medication;
Psychological/emotional
Depression / anxiety / panic attacks;
Self-harm; and
Attempted suicide.

None of the above is absolute evidence that abuse has definitely occurred, but Managers should be alert to the recognised physical, emotional and behavioural indicators that can raise concerns that a member of staff may be experiencing domestic abuse.
Domestic Abuse - Guidance for Managers

It should never be assumed that someone else will take care of domestic abuse issues – a manager or colleague may be the first and only person that the victim tells. However, it is not the job of the line manager to give advice to someone experiencing domestic violence on what action they should take as this is a job best carried out by trained professionals i.e. specialist external organisations.

Ill-informed advice, (however well-intentioned), such as to leave the abusive relationship, can be positively dangerous. In some cases, individuals who leave their partners can face an increased risk of more serious assault and even murder. However, managers should provide the member of staff with information about where they can go for help and how to contact local services. Useful contacts are listed at Appendix

How a manager responds to someone who tells them about domestic abuse is of great importance. It may have taken them many months or years to reach the point at which a victim is able to disclose the abuse. How the victim is treated may make the difference and enable them to disclose more and seek help. Victims often feel ashamed, humiliated and frightened and the fear of not being believed, or of being blamed for what has happened, may stop someone from talking about their experience. When a disclosure has been made, it is essential that the response is sympathetic, supportive and non-judgemental. Any suggestion on the part of the listener that they are sceptical or feel that the victim is to blame may drive the victim back in to isolation and violence.
The Camden Multi-Agency Domestic Violence Forum has highlighted the importance to victims of domestic violence of:
being asked
being believed
being treated with respect
being given time
being given information

It is important to give staff confidence that any issues they disclose will be treated in confidence. However, the individual should be informed that if it is believed that a child or vulnerable adult is at risk of abuse or neglect as a result of the information given, advice should be sought. Advice (without giving details of the person or people involved if you do not wish to) can be sought from:
The Trust's Child Safeguarding Team
The Trust's Adult Safeguarding Team
The on-call Paediatrician
Human Resources
Social Services
Staff counselling service (via Occupational Health)
The Line Manager should also refer to the Data Protection and Code of Confidentiality Policies.
Practical steps that can be taken to help and support staff

6.7.1 It is important to ask the member of staff what they feel the Trust can do to support them and to keep them safe, as they are the best judge of their situation. However, some ideas / reasonable adjustments about what can be done support the staff member (which should always be done with their prior consent) includes:
Involve Human Recourses: The HR Welfare Officer can provide advice on accessing childcare and information on support groups.

Adjustments to work patterns: Agreeing a change of shifts or hours they work on a temporary or permanent basis to avoid them travelling in the dark or to ensure that the person abusing or stalking them does not know when they will be at work.

Temporary place of working: Looking at vacancies in other areas of the Trust to redeploy them on a temporary or permanent basis to a different ward, department, location or role if they think this could help with their situation. Human Resources can help with this and exceptions can be made to the usual recruitment processes (with the authorisation of the HR Business Partner) to facilitate staff safety and wellbeing.
Support from Hospital Security Team: Alerting security to any issues and asking for their help e.g. escorting the individual to and from their car or the bus stop at the start and end of their shift.

Safe care parking: The Car Parking Manager can be contacted in confidence and can provide support and advice with car parking (usually on a temporary basis until the issues have been resolved) so that the member of staff can park somewhere on site where they feel safe.

Support from Occupational Health Department: Staff experiencing domestic abuse may not only have higher sickness absence, but may also be more vulnerable to stress at work. If appropriate and with their consent, you may refer them to Occupational Health for advice on how to best support them and for counselling to help them cope with the issues. Staff can also self-refer in confidence.

Supporting staff member to safely access support services: If the member of staff is worried about accessing advice and support from specialist organisations who can help e.g. because their partner checks their phone and internet usage, the Trust can make contact on their behalf (only with their consent). You may want to give the staff member paid time away from their duties and access to an office/telephone/computer to enable them to make this contact in private.

Support with reporting acts of crime: Domestic abuse may often involve a criminal offence. You can contact the police on behalf of your member of staff (again with their consent) and ask them to visit them in a suitable location at work where they can discuss your concerns with them in private.

Agree actions to improve safety whilst at work: The Trust can work with the member of staff to agree a plan of what to do if the perpetrator of the abuse tries to telephone the member of staff at work or tries to come into the area where they work. Think about briefing staff in

your department or ward generally about what to do if someone telephones for a member of staff and how to deal with enquiries about whether a staff member is on shift or when they are next due at work. Think about changing codes on security locks on doors on a regular basis.

Support with time off to attend meetings etc.: You can agree time off from work to enable the member of staff to access support from specialist agencies, to attend counselling, to seek advice from a solicitor, to make alternative childcare arrangements and to attend meetings with schools. Employees may also need time off to attend hearings as a witness (in either the civil or criminal courts) or to attend court to seek an injunction in cases of violence or harassment. Your Employee Relations Advisor can advise on this further and you do not need to give any details of the individual when asking a general question about time off.

Agreeing systems to know the whereabouts of the staff member: Consider agreeing a system to ensure that someone is aware of the employee's whereabouts whilst they are at work. If their role requires them to work outside the ward/department discuss with them changing their duties, issuing them with a personal alarm or agreeing a system whereby they telephone in on a regular basis.

Keep a record of evidence: Discuss making a record of persistent phone calls, e-mails, texts or visits to an employee by their partner/ex-partner so that this is available in future should they wish to report this to the police, apply for an injunction or use the evidence to support applications for support with housing.
Changes to staff members payroll: If the employee's partner has access to their finances or is exerting financial pressure on them, discuss changing salary payments into a different account.

Support with housing / places of safety: Housing may be an issue. Discuss sources of support such as the employee's local Citizens Advice Bureau or council housing office and consider contacting the Estates and Facilities department to see if Trust accommodation may be an option.

Consider court injunctions: The Trust can apply for an injunction against an alleged perpetrator if their actions impinge on the health and safety of employees. Contact your HR Business Partner for further advice, if you feel this is required.

Ask the staff member what support they want and make them aware of internal and external support services including the Trust Safeguarding Team. A full list of external support services can be found in Appendix 4 of this document.

6.7.2 The recognised risk assessment tool used by this TRUST is the Domestic Abuse, Stalking and Harassment and Honour based violence (DASH 2009) Risk Identification and Assessment and Management Model. The assessment tool can be found on the Staffnet or by contacting the Safeguarding Teams

6.7.3 Managers must take into account whether the above measures (or other requests from employees) are operationally practical or appropriate and the needs of the service should still be considered. However, ensuring the safety of employees must be borne in mind throughout this process.
Stalking

Stalking is a crime as set out in the Protection from Harassment Act 1997. Stalking may be perpetrated by a partner or former partner and can be linked to domestic abuse. However, it can also be carried out by strangers or by someone with whom the individual has had contact e.g. in a professional setting as a patient or client.
The following are examples of stalking behaviours:
Watching/maintaining surveillance/following someone
Standing or loitering near the victim
Driving past the person's home or workplace
Telephoning/mailing/e-mailing/leaving graffiti
Taking photos without permission
Giving unwanted gifts
Sending bizarre or sinister items to the victim
Inappropriately researching private information about an individual e.g. via the internet
Stalking should not be taken lightly as it is not only a crime in its own right but can escalate to include more serious offences such as:
Death threats
Suicide threats
Criminal damage/vandalism
Refusing to accept that a professional relationship e.g. between medical professional and patient is over
Confining the person against their will
Verbal threats/gesturing or acts of symbolic violence
Sexually unwanted behaviours
Sexual and/or violent assault

Much of the same support and information applies to members of staff who feel that they are being subjected to stalking as to staff who are victims of domestic abuse. The Trust would want staff to feel able to tell someone in confidence about an abusive situation so that the Trust can help and support. But it is recognised that this can be very difficult to do. It is important that the Trust protects its entire staff, and stalking may pose a risk to the victim as well as to other colleagues.
If a staff member does disclose an abusive situation such as stalking, there are a number of different people the member of staff can talk to including:
Line manager
A senior manager
A member of the HR Operations team (HR Business Partners or Employee Relations Advisors)
A Trade Union representative
Occupational Health
It would help the Trust to assess any risks and put in place security measures if any incidents of stalking are reported via an incident form via Datix.
Stalking Risk Assessment
7.7.1 The Line Managers should carry out a risk assessment with the member of staff. The Adult Safeguarding Team can be contacted for guidance / tools that can be used to guide the risk assessment.
7.7.2 If a member of staff discloses stalking they should be advised to:
Treat any threats as real and inform the Police and the staff members Line Manager (or another senior manager) immediately.

Keep any evidence e.g. notes, recordings of voicemail messages or telephone calls, items and give these to the Police, bearing in mind that they could contain DNA or other evidence which may be used as part of a criminal case. Keep a written log of incidents. You may find the template stalking and/or domestic abuse record later in this document useful.
Keep a list of important telephone numbers to hand at all times, for example Police, Security etc.
Alert people to the situation who may be useful in formulating a contingency plan e.g. line manager, security manager, close friends and family.
Maintain an unlisted phone number. If harassing calls persist, notify the Police.
Vary travel routes and times and try to vary patterns of behaviours e.g. when and where the staff member does shopping, how a staff member travels to work or where they go out with friends.
Inform a trusted neighbour and/or colleagues about the situation and provide them with a photo or description of the suspect and details of any vehicle(s) he/she may drive.
When out of the house or work environment, try not to travel alone if at all possible, and try to stay in public areas.
If the staff member needs help, shout "FIRE" to get immediate attention, as people more readily responds to this cry for assistance than to any other.
Answer the phone by saying 'hello', not stating name or job title. If the caller rings again ask a work colleague to answer the phone.

If the staff member finds out who is stalking them they should not confront the stalker or even engage them in conversation. The staff member should not, under any circumstances, agree to a meeting with them.

Do not respond in any way to calls, letters, or conversations. If the staff member ignores the phone nine times and picks it up on the tenth, there is a risk of sending the message that persistence pays. Once a perpetrator / stalker have gained the attention of a victim, they will be encouraged to carry on.
Protect personal information – shred discarded mail, be wary of unsolicited inquiries, find out how much information there is about the victim of stalking on the Internet.

If staff member thinks they are being followed, they should NEVER go back home. This action will can give the stalker knowledge of where the individual lives. If the individual thinks they are being followed, they should NEVER, go to the house of a friend or family member. If the individual is being followed they should drive to the nearest Police station and contact the Police on a mobile telephone.

An essential part of safety planning is minimizing contact with the stalker. The individual being stalked should tell the stalker only once (through registered mail or through a solicitor) to stop harassing them, and never communicate again under any circumstances.
Guidance for Managers

7.8.1  The HR Operations Team (HR Business Partners and Employee Relations Advisors) are there to help staff with situations such as this. If a member of staff approaches a line Manager with concerns that they are being stalked, each case will be different but key principles include:

Encourage the member of staff to complete an incident form (or complete one with them or on their behalf) for each and every incident so that Security and other relevant departments are aware of the issues and can undertake a risk assessment and provide support. This will also help to identify if the frequency of incidents or pattern of behaviour is getting worse.

Discuss contacting the Police. Encourage the member of staff to report incidents for their own safety and help them to do so if they wish. This could include calling the police on their behalf (with their consent) and providing work time and resources e.g. an office or meeting room for meetings with the police.

Work with the member of staff to record as many details about the offender as possible, e.g. Name (if known), description (age, build, height, eye colour, hair colour and style, clothes worn, vehicle driven etc.), and home address or place of work of the offender). You may find the template stalking and/or domestic abuse record later in this document useful.

Meet with the member of staff to discuss practical steps you could take to help them feel safer. This will involve recording what has happened, identifying the risk and putting together a safety plan. This involves thinking through short and long-term options in advance, ensuring that there is a plan in place about how the member of staff can access help in emergencies, and having the information about services and resources which are available before they are needed.

A safety plan could include provision for emergency accommodation (in case the member of staff has to leave home without warning) as well as temporary and permanent relocation options. It may include changing the employee's place of work and/or shifts on a temporary or permanent basis. A review should be undertaken of what information about the member of staff is available and accessible to the public e.g. details of their work and role on the hospital website, pictures or articles in publications, extension number and department listed with Switchboard. You may wish to discuss changing aspects of their role e.g. if they are a lone worker. You should involve the member of staff in these discussions and encourage them to identify what support they feel could help.
Staff Accused of Domestic Abuse or Stalking - Guidance for Managers
This should be dealt with in the same way as any other complaint of inappropriate behaviour. As a Line Manager you should:
Guidance for Staff

8.2.1 If a complaint is made to the Trust about the behaviour of a member of staff, this will be fully investigated under the Trust Disciplinary Policy. As part of this process, the member of staff will have the opportunity to present their side of the story.

8.2.2 Individuals who are the subject of a complaint sometimes raise counter complaints in order to defend themselves, but this is usually an unproductive step and can delay resolution of matters. If a staff member is the subject of a complaint, they do not need to raise a counter complaint in order to put their side of events forward, as they will be given opportunity to do this as part of the investigation process and all evidence will be examined fairly and impartially.

8.2.3 If there is found to be evidence to support the complaint, the Trust may bring disciplinary proceedings. Where the Trust considers a complaint through the Disciplinary Procedure, the staff member will have the rights set out in that procedure. They will have the right to be informed of the allegations against them, to put their side of the story and to be accompanied to meetings by a trade union representative or work colleague.

8.2.4 Many incidents of domestic abuse will also be a criminal act. Any internal investigation will be separate from any criminal prosecution and the test to be used in determining whether disciplinary action is appropriate in employment terms is the “balance of probability” and not “beyond all reasonable doubt”. It is therefore common to consider allegations through the Trust's internal procedures and to reach a decision on these before a court has decided on the criminal offence. Issues will usually still go through an internal process if a court has delivered  a  “not  guilty”  verdict.  Please  see  Guidance  Note    (Conduct  outside Employment) in the Trust's Disciplinary Procedure for more information.

8.2.5 The Trust will treat disclosures of domestic abuse and/or stalking sensitively and maintain confidentiality  as  far  as  reasonably  possible.  Investigation  of  allegations  will  normally require limited disclosure on a "need to know" basis. For example, some details may have to be given to potential witnesses but the importance of confidentiality will be emphasised to them.

8.2.6 If the complaint against the member of staff is upheld, on a balance of probabilities, at a disciplinary hearing a penalty may be imposed up to and including dismissal, having regard to the seriousness of the offence and all relevant circumstances. If the complaint is upheld, but the member of staff is not dismissed, the Trust could decide to transfer the individual to another post.

8.2.7 In  addition,  staff  who are found  to  have  been  perpetrators  of  domestic  abuse and/or stalking, but who are not dismissed, may have additional conditions placed upon their continued employment. This could include demotion, moving to an alternative role or site, or undertaking additional steps such as seeking help and support from an organisation such as Respect or participation in specialist counselling or an anger management course.

8.2.8 Staff members must not victimise a person who has made a complaint against them or anyone who has supported the complaint or given evidence in relation to such a complaint. Disciplinary action will be taken against a staff member if the Trust has good reason to think that they may have victimised the complainant or someone else.

8.2.9 Refusal to participate in a process designed to restore or improve working relationships may lead to disciplinary action, one or both parties being moved to alternative roles or other management action. This is because it is essential that effective working is restored to ensure the business of the Trust is not compromised.
Training Requirements
Domestic abuse is included as part of the Trust Safeguarding Training which all staff are required to attend and additional training can be provided to specific areas, as requested.
A number of training tools, including e-learning can be accessed via the SETDAB website on the following link:
Domestic Abuse Basic Awareness ELearning Guidance - Southend and Thurrock Domestic Abuse Partnership (setdab.org)

Appendix 1: Background Information

There is a common view that domestic abuse is a private matter and many people are reluctant to get involved. However, it is important to be aware of the damaging effects of domestic abuse both on the immediate victims and more widely. The impact of domestic abuse is often underestimated

data.text: Appendix 2 – Guidance for staff (handout)

If you are suffering from domestic abuse or stalking there is a lot of support and help available to you. The Hospital would like you to feel able to tell someone in confidence about your situation so that we can help, but understand that this can be very difficult to do.
If you do feel able to tell someone about your situation, there are a number of different people you can talk to including
Your line manager
Any senior manager
A member of the HR Operations team (HR Business Partners or Employee Relations Advisors)
Security
A Trade Union representative
Occupational Health
CIC – Employee Assistance Programme

You do not have to be experiencing violence to need support – you may be undergoing any kind of abuse - psychological, physical, sexual, financial or emotional. Domestic abuse is not always carried out by partners but may also be from other family or members, for example in cases of honour based violence.
What can the Trust do to help? Domestic Abuse

First of all, anything you disclose to us will be treated in the strictest confidence. The only time when we will need to tell anyone about information you share with us is if we believe that a child or vulnerable adult is at risk of harm or neglect. If we do feel that we need to tell someone, we will talk to you about this first. We will not tell your colleagues and we will not put any information on your personal file.

We can do many practical things to make you safer at work and can provide emotional support. What we do will depend on your personal circumstances and what you feel comfortable with, but these can include:
Changing your shifts or the hours you work on a temporary or permanent basis to avoid you travelling in the dark or to ensure that the person abusing you does not know when you will be at work.
Looking at vacancies in other areas of the Trust to redeploy you to a different ward, department, location or role if you think this could help with your situation.
Alerting security to any issues and asking for their help.
Providing support and advice with car parking (usually on a temporary basis until the initial issues have been resolved) so that you can park somewhere on site where you feel safe.
Referring you to Occupational Health for counselling to help you cope with the issues. You can also self-refer in confidence.

If you feel worried about accessing advice and support from specialist organisations that can help you, we can make contact on your behalf (only with your agreement) or give you time and access to an office/telephone/computer to make this contact in private.
We can contact the police on your behalf and ask them to visit you in a suitable location at work where you can discuss your concerns with them in private.
We can agree a plan of what to do if the perpetrator of the abuse tries to telephone you at work or tries to come into the area where you work.
We can agree time off from work with you to enable you to access support from specialist agencies.
The Childcare and Family Support Team can provide advice on childcare and can help you to find suitable childcare places.
Why should I tell my line manager?

You may not feel comfortable speaking to your line manager but do try and speak to someone in your line management chain if possible. It is important that you do this because as well as being able to help:
There may be a health and safety issue for you and your colleagues which they need to assess and manage

There may be issues with your performance, your attendance at work or lateness which has a good explanation. These issues can lead to warnings being given or even to members of staff losing their jobs. If your manager is aware of the issues, they can take these into account.
Please think about what you feel would help to make you feel safe and supported and discuss the options with someone suitable.

If you do not feel able to tell someone at work about your situation, please consider contacting one of the organisations listed in Appendix 4 (Sources of Support). These are staffed by trained, professional people who have experience of all kinds of situations and who can help in both emotional and practical ways.
The most important thing is to keep you safe. Always phone 999 for immediate assistance in an emergency
Keeping Yourself Safe
The following guidance is provided by Safer Places, an independent domestic abuse charity dedicate to supporting adults and children affected by domestic abuse.

You and your children's safety should always come first. Although the suggestions below may improve your safety, they will not guarantee it. Remember, you will have the best understanding of your abuser's behaviour, so only do what you think will help.
If you are still in an abusive relationship:
Call 999 in the event of an emergency. Think of alternative ways to keep safe if the police do not respond straight away.

Teach your children what to do in an emergency. Tell them to call 999 and be able to give the address but not to get involved. They should never use a phone in front of the abuser as this may endanger them.
Plan an escape route from every room in your home.
Think of a safe area in your home to go if an argument happens. Stay away from rooms with no exits, hard surfaces, or where there are objects which can be used as weapons e.g. the kitchen.
Make a list of safe people to contact. If possible memorize all important phone numbers.
Speak to a trusted neighbour about your situation who will call the police if they hear a disturbance.
Develop a ‘code word' or ‘sign' so that family and friends know when to call for help.
Keep your mobile telephone charged and with you at all times. In addition have some money/change with you at all times, and know where the nearest working phone box is.

Think about what you will say to your partner if they become violent. Use your judgment of the abuser to protect you and your children. You are in no way colluding with the abuser if you give them what they want in order to protect you and your children.
Know where to go and what to do in an emergency and have an alternative.
You may also be able to do some of the following:
Keep a record of the violent and controlling behaviour to support any future action you may take; civil or criminal.
Log incidents with the police, even if you do not want to press charges at present
Seek legal advice.
Have any bruises or injuries recorded by a doctor for future use in any legal proceedings or re-housing procedures. You can also take a picture using a camera or your mobile phone.
If you are planning to leave

You may not feel able to leave immediately, but you can plan and be prepared for if an emergency does arise and you need to leave your home. Leaving is often the most dangerous time, so planning this can increase your safety.
You can:
Have a packed bag ready and keep it in a secret but accessible place, so you can leave quickly.

Keep important documents (e.g. marriage/ birth certificates, national insurance card, passport, driving license, legal documents), money, medication, and items of sentimental value in a safe place so that they can be grabbed in a hurry.
Only tell people you trust where you will be. Lie if you have to, as this may protect you and them.
Always try to take your children with you or make arrangements to leave them with someone safe.

If the last number you called was a refuge, taxi or the place you are going to stay, dial another number, for example, the Speaking Clock (dial 123) afterwards to prevent anyone from identifying the number you called and finding out where you are going.
Appendix 3 - Guidance for Managers
What could I do if a member of staff tells me that they are a victim of domestic abuse? (See main procedural document for more detailed advice on each of the following actions)
When supporting a staff member, it is important that the individual feels supported:
Make sure discussions are private and that you keep confidentiality
(unless you believe a child or vulnerable adult is at risk of abuse or neglect)Listen seriously, supportively and non-judgementally to what they say
Take responsibility - never assume that someone else will take care of domestic abuse issues as you may be the first and only person that the victim tells.
Do not advise the employee what to do
Provide the employee with details of organisations which can help (see Appendix 2) and the section in this policy on guidance for staff (see Pages 15-18).
Understand that they might need time to decide what to do
Never criticise a victim for not leaving a perpetrator
Ask the victim what they would like you to do e.g. to help keep them safe at work.

Seek expert input if you are unsure what to do. You can speak in confidence to a member of the HR Operations Team, the Trust's Counsellor or the Adult Safeguarding Lead for advice and help. Security may also be able to help.

Further information is available on Staffnet or staff can contact Occupational Health by telephone through the hospital switchboard.

It is available 24 hours a day, 365 days a year and offers independent, free and confidential advice on a variety of issues including counselling, emotional and wellbeing support, financial, tenancy, consumer benefits, employment and health. The FREEPHONE telephone number is 0800 085 1376 or you can access the service confidentially online at www.well-online.co.uk.

Staff are advised to contact either their Trade Union Steward, whose contact details should be on the Staffside notice boards around the Trust, the Staffside Office, or the Head Office of their Union, who will be able to put them in touch with an appropriate local representative.
Security Team

If you feel concerned for your personal safety, you can contact the security team who are based on the main hospital sites  hours per day 7 days a week or contact the Head of Security/ LSMS who will be able to advise and support you in any way deemed necessary.
The security Team/Head of Security can be contacted via switchboard.

They provide free and confidential support and information to help victims of crime to deal with their experience. Victim support has a website http://www.victimsupport.org.uk/ and a national telephone support line – 0808
The contact details for the local Essex office are: 0808 17 81 694 (8am - 5pm Monday-Friday)

Appendix 5 – Information for perpetrators of domestic violence

Perpetrators carry out a wide range of different types of abusive behaviour. Perpetrators of domestic violence tend to be abusive in all of their partner relationships if no direct action (for example by the criminal justice system and/or a perpetrator's programme) is taken to change this type of behaviour.

The perpetrator is the person who has a problem and who needs to change. Domestic violence is not about 'couple dynamics' and victims are in no way responsible for the violence and abuse used against them.
Have you abused your partner or ex-partner in any of the following ways?
Physical abuse - Hit, pushed, grabbed, slapped, punched, kicked, choked partner or pulled their hair or thrown things at them.
Threats and intimidation - Threatened to harm your partner or their friends, punched walls or doors and smashing things.
Sexual abuse - Forced your ex/partner into having sex or any other sexual acts, pressurized or coerced your ex/partner into having sex, sulked or punished them for not satisfying your sexual desires.
Jealousy or isolating behaviour - Tried to control who your partner sees, checking up on them, stopping them from seeing particular friends or family.
Emotional abuse - Constantly criticised them or put them down, humiliated them, laughed at them, ignored them
Using kids - Threatened to hurt the children, saying your partner will not see the kids if they leave you, putting your partner down in front of the children.
Financial abuse - Controlled your partner's money, making them feel like they have to beg for things.

If you have used any of these behaviours towards a partner, you are being abusive. No matter how angry you feel it is never all right to scare or hurt your partner. There are avenues of support within the Trust and a member of staff who believes they are perpetrating domestic violence should feel able to seek support via their Line Manager, the Adult Safeguarding Team or Human Resources.
